results.headline: Bye-Bye, Bong. Hello, Baby.
results.summary_short: It may be a bit, um, premature to say so, but Judd Apatow’s “Knocked Up” strikes me as an instant classic, a comedy that captures the sexual confusion and moral ambivalence of our moment.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Knocked Up

results.headline: Ancient Aboriginal Tales, Parallel Across Epochs
results.summary_short: There is nothing more enthralling than a good yarn, and “Ten Canoes” interweaves two versions of the same story.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ten Canoes

results.headline: Cloistered in the Castle and Dreaming of His Empire
results.summary_short: With “The Fifth Empire,” the prolific 98-year-old director Manoel de Oliveira pushes his minimalist style as far as it can go.
results.display_title: The Fifth Empire - Yesterday as Today

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Fifth Empire - Yesterday as Today

results.headline: Tragedy, Too, Is in the Eye of the Beholder
results.summary_short: Love is blind, and so too is Linda Pugach, one of the loony-tuners in the somewhat sickening, mildly gonzo documentary “Crazy Love.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crazy Love

results.headline: A Father With Two Careers, in Business and in Murder
results.summary_short: In “Mr. Brooks,” serial killing is an addiction that sufferers hope to overcome by attending 12-step meetings.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mr. Brooks

results.headline: Soccer Dreams and Family Tensions
results.summary_short: A familiar underdog story told with unusual sensitivity, Davis Guggenheim’s “Gracie” depicts the obstacles faced by a young girl who dreams of playing on her high school soccer team.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gracie

results.headline: Rejoining the Champions of Light and Dark
results.summary_short: Unfolding in a decrepit, present-day Moscow, “Day Watch” dazzles and confuses with equal determination.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Day Watch

results.headline: Tales of a Small-Town Hero
results.summary_short: Sweetness and whimsy fill the screen to capacity in “I’m Reed Fish,” a rural coming-of-age tale that’s so laid-back that its cast is almost horizontal.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I'm Reed Fish

results.headline: Beating Writer’s Block
results.summary_short: “Four Lane Highway” stars Frederick Weller as Sean, a famous (dead) writer’s son who became a writer himself but has been blocked for some time.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Four Lane Highway

results.headline: Life in the Sprawling Suburbs, if You Can Really Call It Living
results.summary_short: Blending documentary elements and some dramatic material, “Radiant City” is an acerbic position paper on the cultural damage done by postwar architectural fads.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Radiant City

results.headline: In a Crowded Anime Dreamscape, a Mysterious Pixie
results.summary_short: In “Paprika,” a gorgeous riot of future-shock ideas and brightly animated imagery, the doors of perception never close.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paprika

results.headline: Those Tired, Those Poor: A Journey as Important as Its Destination
results.summary_short: Some version of the immigrant’s tale told in “Golden Door” is part of the family history of millions of Americans.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Golden Door

results.headline: Movie Memories and Gender Confusion
results.summary_short: A gentler, more wistful Henry Jaglom wrote and directed “Hollywood Dreams,” his 15th and perhaps most accessible film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hollywood Dreams

results.headline: A Study of Male Family Dynamics
results.summary_short: “Steel City” tells the story of a man and his sons, who struggle with personal and financial demons in a drab Midwestern town.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Steel City

results.headline: On the Edge, a Man Finds Hope in a Mystery Woman
results.summary_short: “Angel-A,” filmed in ravishing black and white, is a valentine to Paris, the City of Light.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Angel-A

results.headline: The Lies People Tell
results.summary_short: “Magic Mirror” is a droll comedy about the impossibility of shaking the burdens of your dreams and obligations.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Espelho Magico

results.headline: The Personal Within the Political
results.summary_short: “Amu,” the ambitious debut feature by Shonali Bose, wears its political heart on its sleeve and is unafraid to tackle big topics: identity, history, truth, injustice.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Amu

results.headline: Creepy Crawly Conspiracies
results.summary_short: With “Bug,” William Friedkin continues to be more fascinated by the evil inside our heads than the boogeyman outside.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bug

results.headline: Back to the Bounding Main
results.summary_short: “At World’s End” is the third and perhaps final episode in the swishy, swashbuckling “Pirates of the Caribbean” saga.
results.display_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End

results.headline: The Difficulty of Death
results.summary_short: In a movie culture filled with fake death and callous killing, “Dying at Grace” is not just a shock to the system; it’s an accusation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dying at Grace
